cit28.CITATION: As pointed out in ref. [8], the uncertainties of the reconstructed EoS are dominated by poorly constrained eigenmodes, which typically oscillate more rapidly than well determined eigenmodes do.

cit29.CITATION: One can thus reduce the EoS uncertainties by filtering out such eigenmodes in the result [8, 23], though the final EoS and its errors would depend on the number of eigenmodes being kept [12, 14].

cit30.CITATION: One can thus reduce the EoS uncertainties by filtering out such eigenmodes in the result [8, 23], though the final EoS and its errors would depend on the number of eigenmodes being kept [12, 14].

cit31.CITATION: One can thus reduce the EoS uncertainties by filtering out such eigenmodes in the result [8, 23], though the final EoS and its errors would depend on the number of eigenmodes being kept [12, 14].

cit32.CITATION: One can thus reduce the EoS uncertainties by filtering out such eigenmodes in the result [8, 23], though the final EoS and its errors would depend on the number of eigenmodes being kept [12, 14].

cit33.CITATION: Another way to reduce the EoS uncertainties is to regularize the reconstruction process with a correlation prior to suppress fast-varying modes in the posterior distribution of {wi} [26].

cit34.CITATION: Recent applications of this method have shown preference for dynamical dark energy over the cosmological constant at more than 3σ significance level [11].

cit35.CITATION: Section 2 describes the method of nonparametric reconstruction of the dark energy EoS with the correlation prior and reproduces the result in ref. [11].

cit47.CITATION: We implement a cosmological parameter estimation program ClassMC 5 to reconstruct the dark energy EoS, which incorporates the Boltzmann code CLASS [27, 28, v2.5.0] (modified to allow the dark energy EoS to evolve arbitrarily) and the affine-invariant ensemble sampler [29] IMCMC 6 [30].

cit48.CITATION: We implement a cosmological parameter estimation program ClassMC 5 to reconstruct the dark energy EoS, which incorporates the Boltzmann code CLASS [27, 28, v2.5.0] (modified to allow the dark energy EoS to evolve arbitrarily) and the affine-invariant ensemble sampler [29] IMCMC 6 [30].

cit50.CITATION: We implement a cosmological parameter estimation program ClassMC 5 to reconstruct the dark energy EoS, which incorporates the Boltzmann code CLASS [27, 28, v2.5.0] (modified to allow the dark energy EoS to evolve arbitrarily) and the affine-invariant ensemble sampler [29] IMCMC 6 [30].

cit51.CITATION: For simplicity, we assume a flat geometry and ignore dark energy clustering [31, 32], which are not expected to alter the conclusion of this study.

cit53.CITATION: We use the following observations to reconstruct the dark energy EoS: Planck CMB temperature and polarization power spectra8 [33, 34, Planck -2015], SDSS-II/SNLS3 type Ia supernova (SN Ia) joint light-curve analysis data [35, 36, JLA], BOSS DR12 baryon acoustic oscillation (BAO) measurements of the angular diameter distance D A (z) and the Hubble parameter H(z) in combination with the comoving sound horizon at the drag epoch r d [37, 38], the Hubble parameter H(z) derived from galaxy ages [39, OHD], the Hubble constant H0 = 73.24±1.74 km s−1 Mpc−1 [40], BAO DA (z) and H(z) measurements from the Lyα forest [41], as well as BAO DV (z) measurements from the 6dF galaxy survey [42] and the SDSS DR7 Main Galaxy Sample [43].

cit83.SECTION: Tests in the concordance cosmological model
cit83.CITATION: While we obtain an oscillating EoS similar to that in ref. [11] using largely the same set of observational data, highly resemblant results can also be obtained from ΛJD16 * mock datasets of existing observations that are generated under the flat ΛCDM model.
